conclusion: Before A slides on B, the two blocks move together, so the acceleration is a = F∕(mA+mB).
The straight-line graph a–F passes through the origin, so this relation is obeyed up to the point where sliding just begins.
At the critical force F1 the static-friction limit is reached. From the graph this occurs at F1 ≈ 24 N, with the common acceleration a1 ≈ 3 m s⁻².
The maximum static friction equals μk mA g; at the same critical point that must also equal the horizontal interaction between the two blocks, namely mA a1.
mA a1 = μk mA g ⟹ μk = a1∕g = 3⁄10 = 0.30.
For forces larger than F1 the friction is kinetic, of magnitude μk mA g, and only block A is acted on by F and kinetic friction.
Hence for F>F1 the acceleration of A is a = (F−μk mA g)∕mA, which is linear in F with slope 1∕mA.
From the graph, in this region a grows from 3 m s⁻² at 24 N to 8 m s⁻² at 64 N.
Coefficient of kinetic friction μk = 0.30; mass of block A mA = 8 kg.
